{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3483072,"name":"Santiago Sepúlveda","username":"Sepu2002","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/c67d28/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-15T04:22:23.386Z","cooked":"

I have an issue: I’m trying to make my robot align with the AprilTag on the field using a Limelight. To achieve this, I’m using the 3D model of the AprilTag and extracting the yaw and tx of the target separately. Then, I’m attempting to align the robot horizontally with the AprilTag and ensure the chassis is parallel to it through rotation. However, when tuning the PID, the robot doesn’t precisely reach the target point. The robot “kind of” aligns but then it starts shaking a lot and massively deviates.

This is my code:

image1071×409 26.7 KB

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-01-15T04:22:23.386Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":188,"reads":223,"readers_count":222,"score":984.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":481838,"topic_slug":"limelight-swerve-yaw-rotation-and-strafe-x-axis-align","display_username":"Santiago Sepúlveda","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51602,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/limelight-swerve-yaw-rotation-and-strafe-x-axis-align/481838/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3483382,"name":"Edan Liahovetsky","username":"Etherex","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/etherex/{size}/270323_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-15T15:13:48.325Z","cooked":"

The horizontal setpoint oscillation could be caused by a combination of the pipeline latency and a poorly tuned PID controller. The first thing I recommend trying is to set your translational kP to a value were the robot will oscillate around it’s setpoint were the controller will not compound error. Then, add a kD term to help reduce this oscillation. I see that you have a kI term which is nice. This, of course, is just basic tuning, and compensating for pipeline latency by tracking your robot relative chassis speeds at the time of the vision observation and then doing some trig (I will not outline the calculation here) could reduce latency. If you are using the 3d tracking mode, it could be easier to develop a odometry - vision pose estimation system to circumvent pipeline latency. It is also worth while to profile your translational motion to help increase repeatability of the robot motion.

I would avoid using println statements for debugging, I have experienced it slowing down code execution and causing other issues… I would instead suggest putting values to SmartDashboard and viewing them on the driverstation dashboard

I didnt mean you have to view it on SmartDashboard, I just meant its as easy as a println statement to get it in networktables and view in any dashboard you use…
SmartDashboard.putBoolean(“detectando_apriltag”, true);
and
SmartDashboard.putBoolean(“detectando_apriltag”, false);

Have you tried starting just with P? Maybe your I term is like accumulating hence why you see it kinda line up and then start spazzing out. Or you could clamp the I value to a max so it doesn’t grow too much

Heya, both PID systems work fine independently. If we only run the yaw alignment it works, and if we only run the strafe alignment also. Do you think running them one after the other could help?

We always start with only a P term. After the system oscillates around the setpoint. We use half that value and then slowly turn up the I value to get rid of the steady state error. We only add a D term as an anti-windup mechanism in extreme cases.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-01-15T18:23:16.752Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":81,"readers_count":80,"score":21.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":481838,"topic_slug":"limelight-swerve-yaw-rotation-and-strafe-x-axis-align","display_username":"Santiago Sepúlveda","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":53032,"username":"Traptricker","name":"Jackson Elia","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/traptricker/{size}/215403_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51602,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/limelight-swerve-yaw-rotation-and-strafe-x-axis-align/481838/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3483573,"name":"Scott W","username":"Programming4907","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/programming4907/{size}/168313_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-15T18:26:49.057Z","cooked":"

You could try a different method: Use the ID of the tag you detect, lookup the field-relative angle of the tag based on the ID and set your target heading to that, instead of trying to align to the actual physical tag. Then just align left/right to the center of the tag.

A calibrated Pigeon 2 or NavX2 gyro is accurate enough for the 2.5 minutes of a match.

That sounds like an amazing idea. We already have the ability to lock to a given angle, so this seems like plug and play solution.
